turn.1: Why is the road rally time trial format used?
turn.2: Note that a 30 mph average is still quite high when the type of roads used is considered, especially as this average includes non-competitive link sections that may be timed at a very low average, such as 15 or 20 mph.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: However, with the elimination of commercial sponsorship, less money came into the sport and over time this affected the degree to which cars were able to be prepared by the average competitor.
turn.6: Many of the top road rally crews quickly moved into stage rallies - notable among them was one time Welsh road-rally demon Gwyndaf Evans.
turn.7: Is the format still used today?
turn.8: Road rallies still make up a significant popular element of amateur motorsport in the UK, but most crews graduate to stage rallies, or start with stage rallies rather than serve the traditional road-rally 'apprenticeship'.
turn.10: However, with their emphasis on map reading and navigational skills, they remain a very competitive, fun and worthwhile pursuit for many.
